title: Critical Path Method
description: Master critical path analysis to identify schedule constraints, calculate float, and make optimal compression decisions.
objectives: Identify the critical path as the longest path through a network diagram with zero float
Calculate Total Float using Early Start (ES), Late Start (LS), Early Finish (EF), Late Finish (LF)
Distinguish between Forward Pass (ES, EF calculation) and Backward Pass (LS, LF calculation)
Determine which activities to crash or fast-track when schedule compression is needed
Apply Resource Leveling vs. Resource Smoothing to resolve resource constraints

screens.headline: 12 weeks to launch. Sponsor wants it in 10. Which path is critical?

visual.left: Jordan pointing to network diagram (Path 1 red: 12 weeks, Path 2 blue: 11 weeks)
visual.center: Large '12 weeks' countdown timer with red '-2 weeks' overlay

dialogue.text: Path 1 is 12 weeks, Path 2 is 11 weeks. One of these is our critical path. Compress the wrong one and we've wasted time and money. Which do we focus on?

screens.learningHook: The critical path is the LONGEST path through the project—it has zero float and determines the finish date. Compress a non-critical path? You've accomplished nothing. You'll learn to IDENTIFY the critical path, CALCULATE float, and DECIDE which activities to crash for maximum schedule reduction at minimum cost.

screens.title: Critical Path Analysis & Compression Decisions
screens.instructions: Work through 4 scenarios: identify critical path, calculate float, perform forward/backward pass, and decide which activities to crash.

scenarios.title: Identify the Critical Path
scenarios.description: Path 1: A → B → D → F → H = 12 weeks. Path 2: A → C → E → G → H = 11 weeks.

questions.question: Which path is the critical path?

options.text: Path 2 because it has more activities
Path 1 because it is the longest path (12 weeks)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Path 1 (12 weeks) is critical because it's the longest path.
feedback.incorrect: Critical path = longest path. Path 1 = 12 weeks, Path 2 = 11 weeks → Path 1 is critical.

questions.question: What does this mean for the project?

options.text: Path 1 activities have zero float. Any delay on Path 1 delays the entire project.
Path 2 activities have zero float and must be monitored closely
We can delay any activity by 1 week without impacting the finish date
All activities must finish exactly on their Early Finish dates

feedback.correct: Correct! Critical path activities have zero float—no schedule flexibility.
feedback.incorrect: Only critical path activities (Path 1) have zero float.

scenarios.title: Calculate Float for Path 2 Activities
scenarios.description: Activity C (Vendor Recruitment) is on Path 2. ES = Day 3, Duration = 3 weeks, Critical Path = 12 weeks, Path 2 = 11 weeks.

questions.question: What is the Total Float for Activity C?

options.text: 0 weeks (C is on the critical path)
1 week (Path 1 is 1 week longer than Path 2)

feedback.correct: Perfect! Float = Critical Path Duration - This Path Duration = 12 - 11 = 1 week.
feedback.incorrect: Float for Path 2 activities = 12 weeks (critical) - 11 weeks (Path 2) = 1 week.

questions.question: How should Alex manage Activity C?

options.text: C can be delayed up to 1 week without impacting the finish date. Focus resources on critical path activities.
C must finish exactly on time—any delay is unacceptable
C should be crashed to reduce the project duration
C's float means we can remove it from the schedule entirely

feedback.correct: Excellent! C has float—providing flexibility to prioritize critical path work.
feedback.incorrect: C has 1 week of float. It can be delayed without impacting the project.

scenarios.title: Forward Pass & Backward Pass
scenarios.description: Activity D (Stage Construction) is on the critical path. Predecessor B finishes Day 35. D's duration = 4 weeks (28 days). Project duration = 12 weeks (84 days).

questions.question: What is the Early Start (ES) for Activity D?

feedback.correct: Correct! ES = when predecessor finishes = Day 35.
feedback.incorrect: ES = Latest EF of all predecessors = Day 35.

questions.question: What is the Early Finish (EF) for Activity D?
What is the Late Finish (LF) for Activity D?

options.text: Day 63 (same as EF, because D is on critical path)

feedback.correct: Excellent! Critical path activities have LF = EF (zero float).
feedback.incorrect: D is critical (zero float) → LF = EF = 63.

questions.question: What is the Late Start (LS) for Activity D?

options.text: Day 35 (same as ES, because D is on critical path)

feedback.correct: Perfect! LS = LF - Duration = 63 - 28 = 35. Also LS = ES for critical activities.

questions.question: What is the Total Float for Activity D?

feedback.correct: Correct! Total Float = LS - ES = 35 - 35 = 0. Critical path activities have zero float.

scenarios.title: Which Activities Should Alex Crash?
scenarios.description: Need to compress from 12 weeks to 10 weeks (2-week reduction). Critical path crash options: A (can't crash), B (can't crash - external dependency), D (4 weeks → can crash 2 weeks @ $15K/week), F (2 weeks → can crash 1 week @ $8K/week), H (can't crash - mandatory inspection).

options.text: Crash Activity B (Permit Acquisition) by 2 weeks
Crash Activity D (Stage Construction) by 2 weeks. Cost: $30K
Crash Activity D by 1 week ($15K) and Activity F by 1 week ($8K). Total cost: $23K
Crash Activity C (Vendor Recruitment) by 2 weeks

feedback.correct: Perfect! You found the optimal solution: crash D (1 week @ $15K) + F (1 week @ $8K) = $23K. This is $7K cheaper than crashing D alone.
feedback.incorrect: Review: Find the combination of critical path activities with lowest total crash cost.

content.definition: The critical path is the LONGEST sequence of activities through a project network diagram. It has ZERO FLOAT and determines the minimum project duration.
characteristics: Longest path: Has the greatest total duration
Zero float: Activities cannot be delayed without delaying project finish date
Controls finish date: Project duration = critical path duration
May have multiple critical paths: If two or more paths have the same longest duration

example.path1: A → B → D → F → H = 2 + 3 + 4 + 2 + 1 = 12 weeks (CRITICAL)
example.path2: A → C → E → G → H = 2 + 3 + 3 + 2 + 1 = 11 weeks (non-critical)

content.definition: Float is the amount of time an activity can be delayed without delaying the project finish date (Total Float) or its immediate successor (Free Float).
content.insight: Float is a RESOURCE, not a license to procrastinate. PMs use float to optimize resource allocation.

forwardPass.purpose: Calculate Early Start (ES) and Early Finish (EF)

formulas.es: Latest EF of all predecessors (or Day 1 if no predecessor)

backwardPass.purpose: Calculate Late Finish (LF) and Late Start (LS)

formulas.lf: Earliest LS of all successors (or project finish date if no successor)

content.floatFromDates: Total Float = LS - ES = LF - EF

blocks.title: Schedule Compression: Crashing the Critical Path

content.keyPrinciple: To reduce project duration, you MUST compress the critical path. Compressing non-critical activities is useless.
crashingRules: Only crash activities on the CRITICAL PATH (zero float)
Crash activities with the LOWEST cost per time unit ($/week)
Watch for NEW critical paths: as you crash, non-critical paths may become critical

scenario1_correct.text: Exactly right. Path 1 is critical. Any delay on these activities delays the entire festival launch.

scenario2_correct.text: Perfect understanding of float. C has scheduling flexibility, so we can deprioritize it if needed to support critical path activities.

scenario3_correct.text: Flawless. You understand how to calculate Early/Late dates and recognize that Activity D has zero float because it's on the critical path.

scenario4_correct.text: Brilliant. You didn't just crash the first available activity—you analyzed crash costs and found the cheapest combination.

screens.title: New Scenario: Resource Constraint Forces Re-Analysis
screens.context: After Alex crashes Activities D and F, Jordan discovers a problem: the sound engineer can only work part-time. Activity F will take 2 weeks, not 1 week. This means: Updated Path 1 = 11 weeks, Path 2 = 11 weeks. BOTH paths are now critical.

questions.question: How many critical paths are there now?
What is the float for activities on Path 1 and Path 2?
To compress from 11 → 10 weeks, what must you crash?

options.text: One activity on EACH path (Path 1 AND Path 2)
Crash D on Path 1 AND E on Path 2

items.label: Managing two critical paths increases risk
Any delay on either path delays the project

screens.title: Key Takeaways
screens.summary: You've learned to use the Critical Path Method as a DECISION TOOL for schedule management. By identifying the critical path, calculating float, and analyzing compression options, you can make data-driven decisions about where to focus resources.
takeaways: Critical Path = longest path through the network diagram (zero float, controls project finish date)
Total Float = LS - ES (how much an activity can be delayed without delaying the project)
Forward Pass calculates ES and EF (left-to-right); Backward Pass calculates LF and LS (right-to-left)
Only crash CRITICAL PATH activities—crashing non-critical activities doesn't shorten the project
When multiple paths have the same longest duration, ALL are critical paths (higher risk)
Resource Leveling extends schedule; Resource Smoothing optimizes resources within fixed schedule
